title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and it pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The Social Security Act is amended to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy. This information can be used by federal and state agencies for benefits administration, with safeguards in place to protect against unauthorized use or disclosure. The Commissioner of Social Security is required to share information on deceased individuals for benefits administration, with safeguards in place to protect against unauthorized use or disclosure. Agencies can cooperate with the Commissioner to ensure proper payment of benefits, reimbursing for associated costs. The Commissioner can share information on deceased individuals for various purposes through cooperative arrangements with federal agencies, including operating the Do Not Pay system, ensuring proper payments, and carrying out tax administration or debt collection duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal agencies for purposes such as preventing improper payments, tax administration, and crime investigation. Additionally, similar arrangements can be made with States for state-funded programs or retirement systems. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal and state agencies for statistical purposes and research activities, subject to necessary safeguards. Amendments made to specific sections will be repealed five years after enactment. The amendments made to certain sections of the Social Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code are repealed, restoring the original provisions. Additionally, the Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal agencies for authorized purposes. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for federal agencies, including state agencies, focusing on accuracy, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability compared to data from the Commissioner of Social Security. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will compare alternate sources of death data to that distributed by the Commissioner of Social Security. A report will be submitted to Congress within 4 years, including a recommendation on extending agency access to Social Security death data. SEC. 7. IMPROVING THE USE OF DEATH DATA BY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to enhance government agencies' utilization of death data. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on accessing death databases for improved data matching within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan within 1 year to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing death records electronically to the Federal Government. The plan may include recommendations for statutory changes or financial assistance. Additionally, a report to Congress on improving data matching will be issued. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days to improve data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. Additionally, annual reports on the implementation of this plan will be provided for the next 4 years. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress on the implementation of a plan to improve data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. The report will include recommendations required under subsection (a)(2) and definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA BY SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including individuals not receiving benefits. It includes procedures for identifying elderly individuals still alive according to records, and improving policies to correct erroneous records of living and deceased individuals. The plan required under the Act aims to ensure the accuracy of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration. It includes procedures for identifying living individuals listed as deceased, correcting errors in records, employing statistical analysis to estimate erroneous records, and making recommendations for legislation. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement this plan within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
